EXT:  WASTELAND - NIGHT

The camera is moving across the landscape of a desolate world
shattered by an apocalyptic onslaught of locusts. A distant 
sound comes from below and we are looking up at the sky. We
are standing on a deserted road. We move down the road,
through the empty, dusty land, and into the open land.

The road is deserted except for a few houses, a few children, a few
horses.

We move down the road, into the open land. The road winds
towards a small cave and there is a small cave in
the middle of it.

We come to the edge of the cave and drop into the cave,
looking through the hole as if we were looking through a 
door into another world.

We look through the hole, up onto a long stone wall, then down at the
roars of the horses in the background.

We walk down the wall to the right.

We come to a small ledge and step onto it. We descend as the
rock rises on top of the ledge, up and into the cave.



INT:  CAVE - MORNING

We begin to slide down the rock. The water is dripping
down the rock surface.

Suddenly, we hear a screech and the rock drops to the ground.

We start on it up again and it rocks us back up, as the water is
coastalling with the rock.

The water starts to splash down again. The first
time we have been in the cave, we were underwater. 
We have made it to the top of the cave and have to climb the
steps.  We hold out our hand for the handkerchief we left
behind. The handkerchief turns out to be the same type that the
gendarme gave us in the kitchen.

We start the climb up the wall, as the handkerchief stops working. 
The climbing begins.  The handkerchief breaks and the wall falls
down.

We reach the base of the rock and start to climb.  One by one we
see, from different angles, the handkerchief has separated. 

We climb, and the water keeps pouring down, the water covering
the walls. We climb again, and the water keeps pouring
down. It starts getting light and the handkerchief
is separating again. We are climbing at
half-speed and the water has begun to get dark.

Finally, we reach the top of the wall, where a water-tight, 
cold room looks through a door on the wall. The door 
shakes and the handkerchief is breaking. There are a lot of
doors in this cave. 



EXT:  CAVE - DAY

We see the water at the bottom of the rock, the water on the floor, 
the wall, the ceiling, the ceiling, the ceiling, the wall, 
the ceiling.

In the darkness we have the view of the door of the cave moving up
the wall in the direction of the water.

We look back and see the water falling down into the cave. 
It is a good bit darker now.

We are very close.

Finally, we come close enough to see the handkerchief falling
down. We know that it has started to break,
then it does.

We look at the handkerchief.

We feel ourselves beginning to crawl around the cave
door.

We are looking very different, very dark.

INT: THE VAN




He goes to the driver's seat, still carrying Susan.

He looks back and forth until the man is no longer speaking and he

window. He gives him a look of recognition, which he quickly takes 
off.

in and he looks for the man in the rear  door of the car.

back of the house, then he notices that there is no other man

turns off the car.

EXT.  CARPETED HOUSE - DAY

A CARPETED HOUSE lies in the driveway.  From behind us, the
scene of the murder becomes visible.  It is a cold, barren field. 

The CARPETED HOUSE, covered with tarpaulins and blanket, is dark; it is
empty except for an unfinished brick and a lone wooden tree.  A few
people are standing on the porch.  The sound of the distant
siren grows louder.  They turn off the road and push past the
carpet, moving up the driveway until they enter the house. 

The sound is still louder.  Mick and the others take the same
path to the carpeted house.  There are no windows, only
a white cot.  We can see the house from the front and in
front of it, the sun streams over a single log wall.  At the
front wall are the remains of a couple's wedding present.  


				MICK
		Where is the rest?


				DEPUTY MCCLANE
		It's all right. 

A LITTLE BOY stands up.  He can see the scene.  The scene
is empty, and the little boy is standing alone.  He stares
towards the house, but we don't hear him.  He reaches for a
pot in the corner.  He looks into the pot, but it's full of
tears and blood.  He picks them up, wipes his hands with
the lid, and throws them away.  He doesn't look at
the little boy.  He stands there, stares straight ahead.  Then he
puts his coat and hat back on.


				MICK
		Maybe it's the dog.


				DEPUTY MCCLANE
		Maybe it is, Mick. 

He pulls off his hat.  There are tears in his eyes.


				MICK

As Mick and the others start forward, the noise is
hard to distinguish from the silence in the yard.

into the bark.  The little boy's mother is kneeling on
the ground.  The girl stands close, her hand out
of reach of the boy.
